editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: TO HIS Worthy, and much Honoured Friend, ELIAS ASHMOLE E≈øq One of the Kings Maje≈øties Heraulds at Arms, and Comptroller of the Exci≈øes through all England.
div.p:
HAving but barely, though faithfully Tran≈ølated this Helvetius, treating of the mo≈øt rare and experimental Tran≈ømutation of Metals; I thought
it not fit to make any Dedication, but ≈øeeing I have adjoyned my own Epitaph, with ≈øeveral Scutcheons, Mottos, and Explanations, with Pythagoras his General Figure, Blazoning Philo≈øophical Herauldry, and al≈øo the Alchahe≈øt, Samech' with other Elixirs, &c. I con≈øulted it was very proper to pre≈øent the ≈øame to your Judicious view, who≈øe abilities might challenge the ≈øame, e≈øpecially ≈øince I received ≈øome civilities from you, of a little like Nature, in the ≈ømall intermi≈ø≈øion of my Long troubles, 1662. Likewi≈øe being an Engli≈øhman, who≈øe Patronage in general you ≈øeem to avouch by tho≈øe Worthy Collections of Engli≈øh Philo≈øophick Chymical Authors, formerly publi≈øhed by you. I know you have another Coat of Arms for my Paternal Family, in your Heraulds Office, which would ≈øuit with the ≈øaid Epitaph, if it were only as it is al≈øo intended for a plain Sculpture to be upon my Grave Stone: Yet ≈øuch Scutcheons had not
been ≈øo proper for this place, the≈øe being chiefly here intended for the Philo≈øophers Stone, agreeing with my ≈øaid Epitaph, in the Elements, Principles, and whole perfection thereof, excellently manife≈øted by our late Engli≈øh Phaenix, or Elias Arti≈øto Anonymon, in his Book of The open entrance to the ≈øhut Pallace of the King. Now ≈øome perchance may think it incongruous for any man to publi≈øh his own Epitaph, or annex any ≈øuch Novel Scutcheons. Yet ≈øince they and their Explanations are Philo≈øophick (and the Philo≈øophers Patrons are Truth and Rea≈øon, which ≈øhould govern all ≈øorts of men) I was the more confident of allowance and approbation. And indeed Sir, I may affirm, they were made in a Living Grave, 1652. From whence I never thought to come forth no more, then probably Jonas might in the Whales Belly, Daniel in the Lyons Den, or the three Children in the Fiery Furnace, Being grievou≈øly oppre≈ø≈øed and clowded
in my long Troubles, and ≈øince as little regarded. Whereupon I brought him my Cru≈øible wherein it was done, and in≈øtantly b ‚Ä¢ perceived a mo≈øt beautiful Saffron like Tincture ≈øtic ‚Ä¢ on the ≈øides; and promi≈øed to come next morning, by nine in the Morning, and then would ≈øhew me my error, and that the ≈øaid Medicine ≈øhould tran≈ømut ‚Ä¢ the Lead into Gold. Neverthele≈øs I earne≈øtly praye ‚Ä¢ him in the interim to be plea≈øed to declare only for m ‚Ä¢ pre≈øent in≈øtruction, if the philo≈øophick work co ‚Ä¢ much, or required long time. My friend, my frien ‚Ä¢ (≈øaid he) thou art too curious to know all things i ‚Ä¢ an in≈øtant, yet will I di≈øcover ≈øo much; that neithe ‚Ä¢ the great charge, or length of time‚ñ™ can di≈øcourag ‚Ä¢
any; for as for the matter, out of which our Magi≈øtery is made, I would have thee know there is only two Metals and Minerals, out of which it is prepared; but in regard the Sulphur of Philo≈øophers is much more plentiful and abundant in the Minerals; therefore it is made out of the Minerals. He an≈øwered, the Men≈øtrum was a Heavenly Salt, or of a Heavenly Virtue, by who≈øe benefit only the wi≈øe men di≈ø≈øolve the Earthly Metallick body, and by ≈øuch a ≈øolution is ea≈øily and in≈øtantly brought forth the mo≈øt Noble Elixir of Philo≈øophers. But in a Cru≈øible is all the operation done and performed, from the beginning to the very end, in an open fire, and all the whole work is no longer from the very fir≈øt to the la≈øt then four days, and the whole work no more charge then three Florens; and further, neither the Mineral, out of which, nor the Salt, by which it was performed, was of any great price. And when I replyed, the Philo≈øophers affirm in their writings, that ≈øeven or nine Months at the lea≈øt, are required for this work. He an≈øwered, Their writings are only to be under≈øtood ‚Ä¢ y the true Adepti≈øts; wherefore concerning time ‚Ä¢ hey would write nothing certain: Nay, without the ‚Ä¢ ommunication of a true Adept Philo≈øopher, not one ‚Ä¢ tudent can find the way to prepare this great Magi
‚Ä¢ tery, for which cau≈øe I warn and charge thee (as a ‚Ä¢ riend) not to fling away thy Money and Goods to ‚Ä¢ unt out this Art; for thou ≈øhalt never find it To which I replied thy Ma≈øter, (though unknown) ≈ønew

He an≈øwered, In this Art 'tis quite otherwi≈øe; for unle≈øs thou knowe≈øt the thing from the head to the heel, from the Eggs to the Apples; that is, from the very beginning to the very end thou knowe≈øt nothing, and though I have told thee enough; yet thou knowe≈øt not how the Philo≈øophers do make, and break open the Gla≈ø≈øy Seal of Hermes, in which the Sun ≈øends forth a great ≈øplendour with his marvelous coloured Metallick Rayes, and in which looking Gla≈øs the Eyes of Narci≈ø≈øus behold the tran≈ømutable Metals‚ñ™ for out of tho≈øe Rays the true Adept Philo≈øophers gather their fire; by who≈øe help the Volatil Metals may be fixed into the mo≈øt permanent Metals, either Gold or Silver. But enough at pre≈øent; for „Äà‚óä„Äâ intend (God willing) once more to morrow at the ninth hour (as I ≈øaid) to meet, and di≈øcour≈øe further on this Philo≈øophical ≈øubject, and ≈øhall ≈øhew you the manner of Projection. And Secondly attributing the error of my projecting the grand theft of his powder in the dirt of my Nail to his charge, becau≈øe it tran≈ømuted not the Lead that time; And la≈øtly, becau≈øe he gave me too ≈ømall a proportion of his ≈øaid Medicine (as I thought) to work upon ≈øo great a quantity of Lead‚ñ™ as he pretended and appointed for it, Saying further to my ≈øelf, I fear, I fear indeed this man hath deluded me; Neverthele≈øs my wife wrapped the ≈øaid matter in Wax, and I cut halfe an Ounce, or ≈øix Drams of old Lead, and put into a Cru≈øible in the fire, which being melted, my wife put in the ≈øaid Medicine made up into a ≈ømall Pill or Button, which pre≈øently made ≈øuch a hi≈ø≈øing and bubling in its perfect operation, that within a quarter of an hour all the ma≈ø≈øe of Lead was totally tran≈ømuted into the be≈øt and fine≈øt Gold, which made us all amazed as Planets ≈øtruck. Yea, could I have enjoyed Argus's Eyes, with a hundred more, I could not ≈øufficiently gaze upon this ≈øo admirable and almo≈øt miraculous a work of nature; for this melted Lead (after projection) ≈øhewed us on the fire the rare≈øt and mo≈øt beautiful Colours imaginable; yea, and the greene≈øt Colour, which as ≈øoon as I poured forth into ‚Ä¢ n Ingot, it got the lively fre≈øh Colour of Blood; and being Cold ≈øhined as the pure≈øt and mo≈øt refined tran≈øplendent Gold. Truly I, and all ≈øtanding about me, were exceedingly ≈øtartled, and did run with this Aurified lead (being yet hot) unto the Gold≈ømith, who wondred at the finene≈øs, and after a ≈øhort trial of Touch, the judged it mo≈øt excellent Gold in the whole

The next day a rumor went about the Hague, and ≈øpread abroad; ≈øo that many illu≈øtrious Per≈øons and Students gave me their friendly vi≈øits for its ≈øake: Among≈øt the re≈øt the general Say-ma≈øter, or Examiner of the Coynes of this Province of Holland, Mr. Porelius, who with others earne≈øtly be≈øeeched me to pa≈øs ≈øome part of it through all their Cu≈øtomary trials, which I did, the rather to gratifie my own Curio≈øity. div.head: CHAP. IV. I betake me now to the Dialogue between Elias the Arti≈øt, and the Phi≈øician, to expre≈øs what is pa≈øt, and all other pa≈ø≈øages.

sp.speaker: Elias
sp.p: GOd ≈øave you Helvetius? I have heard of your curious ≈øearch after natural things, and read thy Books, particularly again≈øt Kenelme Digbys Sympathetical Pouder, where he glories to to heal all wounds at a di≈øtance. Truly I delight incredibly in all ≈øuch things, which we ≈øee in this Lookgla≈øs naturally implanted in the Creatures, whether Sympathetick or Antipathetick: for the inexhau≈øtible Trea≈øures of the Divine light and Deity (abundantly granted us) may be perfectly known out of the Creatures under the Sky, or in the womb of the Earth, or in the Seas brought forth. sp.speaker: Elias.

Sir, It ≈øeems you have here a whole ≈øhop of the fiery Art of Vulcan, and perhaps all Spagyrical Medicines, mo≈øt exactly drawn out of the Mineral
Kingdom. But Sir? For what end ≈øo many Medicaments? when by a mo≈øt few we may much ≈øooner and ≈øafelyer re≈øtore the health of man, if the di≈øtemper be not deadly, either out of defect of nature, or putrifaction of any noble part, or the whole con≈øumption of the radical humidity; for in ≈øuch de≈øperate ca≈øes neither Galenical Cures, nor Paracel≈øical Tinctures can be helpful; but it is not thus in ordinary di≈øea≈øes, where neverthele≈øs often men are con≈øtrained before their fatal Term, to travail out of this mo≈øt ≈øweet light among≈øt the dead, for want of ≈øpeedy and potent remedies.

sp.speaker: Phi≈øician.
sp.p: Sir, I apprehend by your di≈øcour≈øe you are either a Phy≈øician, or an expert Student in Chymi≈øtry‚ñ™ Verily I believe there are more excellent Medicaments, and an univer≈øal Medicine, which might prolong life‚ñ™ until the determinate end, and al≈øo cure and heal all di≈øtempers in mans body, but who can ≈øhew the way to ≈øuch a Fountain, whence ≈øuch a Medicinal Juice may be obtained, perhaps none amon≈øt men.

sp.speaker: Elias.
sp.p: Truly I am only a Founder of Bra≈øs, yet almo≈øt from my Cradle my Genius prompted me to ≈øearch Curio≈øities in the fiery Art, and I have diligently ≈øearched through the internal nature of Metals, and though now I forbear a≈ø≈øidual labour and accurate Scrutiny, yet ≈øuch labours and lovers are delightful to me; and I believe the mo≈øt high, great and good God, will in this our Age afford his Spagyrick Sons the Metallick my≈øteries gratis yet, by praying, and labouring to attain them.

sp.speaker: Phy≈øician.
sp.p: I grant God affords his commendable good things gratis, yet he hath ≈øeldom given or doth ea≈øily ≈øell to his Sons this Medicinal Nectar for nothing.

For we know certainly that infinite numbers of Chymi≈øts have and do ≈øtill draw water through a Sieve, whil≈øt they pre≈øume to prepare the univer≈øal Stone of Philo≈øophers, and out of the Books of triumphing Adepti≈øts, none can learn the manner of preparing it, or know their fir≈øt matter. And whil≈øt one ≈øearcheth on the lowe≈øt root and foot of the Mountain, he never a≈øcends to the highe≈øt top, where only he can eat and drink the Ambro≈øia and Nectar of the Macro-Sophi≈øts or Philo≈øophers. In the Interim it is the part of a good Phy≈øician, for want of that univer≈øal Elixir, to keep a pure and ≈øafe Con≈øcience, and apply to di≈øea≈øes ≈øuch re≈øtoring remedies in which he certainly finds the effect and Virtue of Curing them. Therefore in all de≈øprate Di≈øea≈øes I u≈øe ≈øuch mo≈øt ≈øimple Medicaments, that the Patients either ≈øpeedily recover, or are brought into ≈øome way of their former better health.

For there are various kinds of Salts generated in the Glandules and Lymphatick Ve≈ø≈øels, after the putrefaction of this or that received nouri≈øhment, which afterwards flouri≈øh out in various humours, and cau≈øe either internal or external di≈øtempers‚ñ™ For experience teacheth us, that as many con≈øtitutions or Complexions, ≈øo many diver≈øities of Di≈øea≈øes, although it be the very ≈øame Di≈øea≈øe in general. As we have experience in them who drink Wine, where divers operations pre≈øently manife≈øt them≈øelves.
For Peter having drunk Wine, pre≈øently begins to be angry and furious on the contrary: Paul ≈øeems to have a Lamblike timidity; but Matthew ≈øings, and Luke weeps.

div.head: CHAP. I. Of the Books of Wi≈ødom, in which the ≈øame may be learned; How and in what manner?
div.p: THere are chiefly but three Books in which all Wi≈ødom is contained. Namely, 1. The whole Nature and Creation, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ great Book of Heaven and „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ 2. The Book of the Holy Writ in the Letter of the Holy word of God. 3. Man him≈øelf. The only Center or Principle of the≈øe three is the word of God, which is the book out of which the≈øe three books have their Original.
The fir≈øt book of Nature contains ≈øeven other books which are the ≈øeven Elements, of which in particular here ‚Ä¢ fter.
The≈øe ≈øeven Books have three other books oppo≈øite, which are the three contrary Elements, of which al≈øo hereafter.

The ≈øecond book, the Holy Writ is divided into three other books, as into the Law of the Old: Into the Go≈øpel of the New: and into the Eternal Go≈øpel of the everla≈øting Te≈øtament and Covenant, which comprehends the book of the Revelation of Je≈øus Chri≈øt.

The Third book of Man is only one book, and is ≈øealed to the blind, but opened to the ≈øeeing. In this book is hidden, ≈øealed; and al≈øo manife≈øt and opened all Wi≈ødom: and man is called the Image or Honour of God: (o ‚Ä¢ which below) and man cannot be called by any other name, 1 Cor. 11. 7.

Out of the fir≈øt book we learn Philo≈øophia the natural Wi≈ødom in and about the knowledge of created natural things which are of the Elements: and we learn this wi≈ødom out of the three Principles and ≈øeven Elements; and di≈øcern the ≈øame from the three contrary Elements, el≈øe we cannot find the truth of the Natural Wi≈ødom.

Out of the ≈øecond book we learn Theologia or Divinity, the wi≈ødom unto Salvation; and that in the three fore≈øaid books through the ≈øeven ≈øpirits, I≈øaiah 11. and we di ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ngui≈øh it from all humane glo≈ø≈øes, and books of Prophane ones. For the book expounds it ≈øelf, and needs no humane interpretation, but only hath need of Faith, which apprehends all things.

Out of the Third Book, which is Gods Image, we learn the true knowledge of God; as al≈øo his being
and e≈ø≈øence, and his whole My≈øtery: in ≈øo much as he that de≈øires to know God, mu≈øt learn to know him in his image, and that perfectly; which perfect knowledge is this, That God is man, and that he is true man, who is of God; and God is in him.

This is the wi≈ødom, that is my≈øtical hitherto, and yet is manife≈øt but only to the wi≈øe: and is called Theo≈øophia; becau≈øe God doth no where ≈øo clearly manife≈øt him≈øelf as in man, who is his image, or honour, or glory, 1 Cor. 11. 7. Therefore man needs not to go far, but only into him≈øelf, to learn the true knowledge of God, and to ≈øeek after God in him≈øelf; and him≈øelf in God. Seeing the three other books proceed only from the one Book, as the world of God, therefore all three do te≈øtifie unanimou≈øly of this book „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , namely each in its letter, wi≈ødom and te≈øtimony, but none ≈øo clearly as man doth. This is that great, whole and perfect Library of wi≈øemen, wherewith in ju≈øtice and equity they may be contented.

All wi≈ødom and knowledg, with their my≈øteries in the≈øe books, we may not learn any where el≈øe, but only through the ≈øame Spirit, who him≈øelf hath penned the≈øe books, made, and te≈øtified. He therefore who is de≈øirous to ≈øtudy the≈øe books, mu≈øt from the bottom of his heart acknowledge and confe≈øs his own blindne≈øs, folly and ignorance; and mu≈øt pray unto the Father of Lights, for illumination, wi≈ødom and under≈øtanding, that he would ≈øend his holy ≈øpirit which may lead us into all truth, and take us away from all fooli≈øhne≈øs. and fal≈øhood, and may bring us to the Light of Gods glory.

Which may not be done by any other means, then
through a love to God, and to mans own ≈øalvation, and through a holy life without all Hypocri≈øie, and through the Light that commeth from above, and not from beneath, from man and his wi≈ødom, which all tho≈øe mu≈øt learn to deny, that de≈øire to learn the wi≈ødom of the holy ones.

We will ≈øpeak thus; That hitherto all the≈øe books were ≈øealed up, but are now opened in the end of the World according to the Prophecy, 4 E≈ød. 6. 20. Dan 12. 9. Zach. 14. 7. And if wi≈øe worldly men are offended at this, they betray them≈øelves, that the wi≈ødom of the holy one is not in them

The books of wi≈ødom te≈øtifie unanimou≈øly of the word by which all things are created, and in which only all wi≈ødom doth re≈øt, and which is the beginning of all beginnings, in which is all, and without which nothing is, which is all in all, God ble≈ø≈øed for ever; Amen.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of tho≈øe principles and beginnings of all things, as al≈øo of God him≈øelf, and of all what≈øoever it be.
div.p:
THe Principle of all Principles, and beginning of all beginnings, as al≈øo of God him≈øelf, is only the word, according to the te≈øtimony of the divine truth and word it ≈øelf, John 1. Now the word may not be defined otherwi≈øe, then that it is a Spirit,
breath or voice of God, yea God him≈øelf in ≈øuch a ≈øub≈øi≈øtence, e≈ø≈øence and being, as namely, How the image of God doth repre≈øent us according to the ≈øimilitude which is man, as that he is a quic ‚Ä¢ ning ≈øpirit, a ≈øpiritual Adam, and heavenly man, which is God the Lord glorined and magnified for ever, Amen.

Now we hold altogether that this is the proper definition of God, and no other, which the holy writ clearly ≈øignifieth. 1 Cor. 15. 45, 47, 48. who according to his Image and Similitude. hath created a ≈øpiritual Adam, and Terre≈øtrial man; when God ≈øaid, Let us make Adam or Man after our image, after our Similitude, Gen. 1. 26, 27.

Now the word being the Beginning of all Beginnings, there is contained in the ≈øame the Light, Life, and Love. The Light affords the Revelation of God, for God is Light, and dwelleth in Light, and is the Father of Lights.
Life is the virtue and power of God, and a quickning Spirit, who hath, createth, and pre≈øerveth all.

Love is a Te≈øtimony of God, in which is the Father, the Son, and the Holy Gho≈øt; in one word which is called Je≈øus Chri≈øt, the ≈øpiritual Adam, and heavenly Man, Me≈ø≈øias, who is E≈ø≈øential, Alpha and Omega. All in All, the Beginning and the End, the Fir≈øt and the La≈øt, Ble≈ø≈øed and Prai≈øed for ever. Amen. Rev. 1. 22.

Now the word being the true Principle in God him≈øelf, then con≈øequently all proceedeth from the word, out of which do chiefly manife≈øt them≈øelves three general Principles, in which Principles, with and through which, all things are contained, and are the≈øe, namely, God, Nature, Element.

Now the≈øe three general Principles afford al≈øo a threefold world, namely a divine uncreated from Godflowing world from Eternity, then an Angelical world, which proceedeth or lighteth forth, or ≈øhineth forth out of the Light in which God dwelleth; and la≈øtly an Elementary world, who≈øe Original came out of the water.

After the≈øe three general Principles, proceed al≈øo three ≈øpecial Principles, namely Gho≈øt, Wind and Water. Now every world hath its proper Gho≈øt, Wind and Water in their Kind and Nature. All things Created out of the divine world from above are Created out of Water and Spirit from above, through the wind and breath of the Omnipotent God; for to the Divine world is properly competent the Spirit; to the Angelical is properly competent the wind, and to the Elementary world is water proper.

After the≈øe ≈øpecial Principles, follow la≈øtly particular Principles, each of which hath its proper Being, out of which, in which, and from which it con≈øi≈øts: But the≈øe three Principles proceed from the former, and are Spirit, Soul, and Life, and Body: All bodies are out of the Water: All Life and Soul out of the Wind: And all Spirit out of the Spirit. But concerning the Angels, their Body is out of the Wind of the Angelical World, their Soul and Life a Fireflame, and their Soul a ‚Ä¢ ight of which el≈øewhere:
The≈øe are our Principles in the Wi≈ødom, out of which all things have their Original: Whether other Principles may be ≈øhewed unto us, we do much doubt.
The Primum mobile, fir≈øt mover of all things is the Word, for in it is the Life.

The Secundum mobile, Second mover of all things,
is the Spirit, through which all things are Created.
The Tertium mobile, Third mover is the Wind, and the≈øe three moving Principles are the Perpetnum mobile, everla≈øting mover of all things, by which all things move, live, and have their Being.

But the≈øe three do re≈øt upon the Water bodily; out of which the World is and all things are: And in the Air; according to the Life, wherein all things are: And in Heaven, from which all things come from above after the Spirit; but the Spirit from God, from which he cometh and returneth thither. John. 1. 4. P≈øal. 104. 30. Acts 17. 28. Eccle≈ø. 12. 7. But all the≈øe come together on and in the Earth, as in the heart of the world. Wi≈ød. 1. 7.

In the≈øe Principles, out, with, and through the ≈øame, ≈øub≈øi≈øt all things: And without the≈øe nothing can ≈øub≈øi≈øt, that is, or hath a Being, and are Light, Life and Love; God, Nature, and Element; Spirit, Wind, and Water; Body, Soul, and Spirit, and that in the Word.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the fir≈øt Principle of all things which is God.
div.p: GOd, being the beginning of all Beginnings; as from which all things proceed, then his beginning is from no other: He is without a beginning, becau≈øe he is not from another; yet though he hath his beginning from no other, he repre≈øenteth in him≈øelf his beginning to all.

This beginning of God is not a beginning to God him≈øelf, but to us; for he him≈øelf is all in all. Now that he might ≈øhew him≈øelf to us men, to te≈øtifie and in≈øtruct us of him, therefore God ≈øheweth him≈øelf in his beginning, which is the Word, which is God him≈øelf.

Now through this VVord is ≈øhewed to us, te≈øtified and taught that, and what God is, and who he is: But without word or ≈øpeaking may be neither Doctrine nor Te≈øtimony, nor a pre≈øentation; as Rea≈øon doth make it manife≈øt. Therefore the VVord is the beginning of God to us, out of which all Te≈øtimonies, Names and Relation of God do proceed; as out of the depths of God, which con≈øi≈øt in their own proper Spirit, wind and water.

The name of God is but one, according to the E≈ø≈øence, which no man knoweth, but only he upon whom he is written, with the living Letters of the Spirit of God, and his VVord E≈ø≈øentially, which is Chri≈øt, and tho≈øe that are of his Being. The≈øe are they in whom the VVord dwelleth E≈ø≈øentially, and that ≈øee his Glory in a Light and Eye that no body el≈øe can ≈øee. All the names of God come together only in this one name: For the whole fulne≈øs of the Godhead dwe leth in him bodily, who is called Alpha and Omega. Zach. 14. 9. Col 2. 9. He that ≈øeeth him ≈øeeth al≈øo God, and the Father, and the living Word, and the quickning Spirit. John 14. 9. 1 John 1. 1 Cor. 15. 45. Even ≈øo he that ≈øeeth man, ≈øeeth al≈øo with the Body, the Soul, and the Spirit, which are in their Nature invi≈øible.

The Te≈øtimony of God con≈øi≈øteth in three: Namely in three witne≈ø≈øes, which are the Father, the VVord, and the Holy Spirit. Now as the name proceeds from the word, ≈øo doth every Te≈øtimony of God, and re≈øteth only upon the dear and true witne≈øs that is called Amen; which is the beginning of Gods Creatures. Rev. 3. 14. And the Te≈øtimony of God ≈øtands thus. God Father, Word, Holy Ghost, Amen, which is Chri≈øt.

Now becau≈øe no body can te≈øtifie of God, but he him≈øelf alone; and all Te≈øtimonies of Truth mu≈øt be ju≈øtified by three: Therefore God al≈øo te≈øtifieth of him≈øelf by three; but they are not three per≈øons, But one onely per≈øon, and one only God; even as in one Earthly mans Body, Soul and Spirit cannot be three di≈øtinct per≈øons, ≈øo in God are not three per≈øons.

But this is the Te≈øtimony of God to us in the Name (non in Nominibus, ≈øed in Nomine) of the Father, Son, and Holy Gho≈øt which con≈øi≈øt in the word, which three are one thing and one: But this Te≈øtimony none acknowledgeth ≈øave he that hath it within him≈øelf E≈ø≈øentially, that is, that hath the Spirit out of God, and is annointed and ≈øealed with it. This is the Te≈øtimony of God with one word, through which we are Sons and Heirs of God. Rom. 8.

La≈øtly, The Revelation of God con≈øi≈øts in ≈øeven Powers, which are the ≈øeven Spirits of God. Rev. 1. 4. Chap. 4. 5. Chap. 5. 6. Zech. 4. 2, 10. And re≈øt upon him who is called, and is Je≈ø≈øe; who is of no other; but out, through, in and of him≈øelf, is is ≈øelf ≈øub≈øi≈øting, in whom is all, who hath all; Al≈øo the fulne≈øs of the Godhead. Rev. 3. 1. I≈øa. 11. Col. 2. 9. For through him all things are Created in Heaven and in Earth, and by him all things are pre≈øerved, by him al≈øo all is Redeemed and reconciled; He Reigneth over all, and hath all under his Power, through him all lo≈øt things are re≈øtored at his glorious coming; He al≈øo holdeth Judgment over all fle≈øh, over quick and dead; And la≈øtly he will make old things new, and will abandon and put away all old things Everla≈øtingly.

Therefore the My≈øtery of God con≈øi≈øts in One, Three and Seven; and according to this My≈øtery all other things are Created and con≈øi≈øt in One, out of Three, through Seven; and are therein te≈øtified, learned, manife≈øted, or ju≈øtified; nothing at all excepted what≈øoever it be; and that for this Rea≈øon That God in his my≈øtery may be learned and glorified in and on all his Creatures.

Herein con≈øi≈øts now the My≈øtery of the VVi≈ødom in its mea≈øure, number and weight, as in One, Three, and Seven, whereby all things are numbred, mea≈øured, and weighed, ≈øo perfectly, that nothing can be added to it, or dimini≈øhed from it. For all the works of God are perfect, and te≈øtifie of the Creator, according to the My≈øtery of the wi≈ødom; namely, that by the works may be known Him, that made them, that what and who he is in his My≈øtery.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the Second Principle, viz. Nature.
div.p: NAture is the ≈øecond Principle and beginning of all things, and ≈øtands betwixt God and the Elements, through which God worketh into the Elements, at, through, and by means, and is in its con≈øideration even as Angelical, who≈øe beginning is out of God a forth-blown Breath, VVind and Air of the Almighty, in which con≈øi≈øts the Soul and Life of all Created things, and every living Soul, and is concentred and fa≈øtened together e≈ø≈øentially, bodily, and ≈øelf-≈øub≈øi≈øting in the Tree of Life, even as God in Chri≈øt, and the whole Elementary world in Man.

This ≈øecond Principle is not everla≈øting according to the beginning‚ñ™ yet eternal according to the end, even as the Angels are. It is not Created out of nothing, as this world; but proceedeth from God, even as the Life from the Spirit, as a Breath, VVind, or Air doth proceed; and is al≈øo the breath of Gods VVord‚ñ™ in which is Life thus, that the ≈øpeaking of the word is a living Eternal Breath, and is di≈øtinct from God, as a living breath or Soul from the quickening Spirit.

The living breath, Soul or Life of all things i ‚Ä¢ according to its Original out of the Nature, but the
Spirit out of God, namely after his mea≈øure, and the body out of the Elements. The Spirit as the Soul, or the Life are di≈øtinct thus: As God, who is Eternal Life, and the quickening Spirit him≈øelf, and hath Life from no other, becau≈øe him≈øelf is the Spirit: And as the living Soul, having her Life not out, from, and by, or through it ≈øelf, but out of the Spirit, which maketh things alive, who≈øe breath is the Life. Now that is ≈øouli≈øh which hath its Life not from it ≈øelf, but from the Spirit, and which is not a Spirit, but only a breath.

All things what≈øoever are in their Being, have the food of thir Souls and Life out of Nature, and that from Heaven through the Wind and Air, from which all that hath breath doth live und feed, as through the forth-going breath of the VVord contained in the ≈øecond Principle; for the word of God feeds every Spirit, Life and Body with its breath or blowing upon; becau≈øe Life is in the word, which beareth all things by his power, even as it hath Created all things.

Now as all things con≈øi≈øt of Body, Soul and Spirit, ≈øo they have three ≈øorts of food to their ilfe & ≈øub≈øtance, the bodily food to the body, out of the Elements, as from that which cometh out of the waters, and out of the Earth, whence al≈øo the body doth come, is taken and is made. The ≈øouli≈øh food to the Soul & Life in every thing out of Nature, through both the Elements of VVind and Air, from whence al≈øo the Life and Soul doth bome. The Spiritual food to the Spirit, and that from God, at from whom the Spirit is, namely each Spirit according to its mea≈øure, and to the Spirit in every way this food cometh from Heaven, through the Spirit and Light, as from the three Spiritual Elements, from whence al≈øo the Spirit did come.
Nature doth a≈ø≈øemble it ≈øelf in her Spirits Life, and body to the wind, Air and water.

The Angelical world in its body is no earth, as the Elementary is, but it is the right body of the water, out of which it ≈øub≈øi≈øteth, and that body is here beneath with us ICE, but above it is an Angelical earth like unto a Chri≈øtal. And in a word, it is a mo≈øt noble Salt of Life, fertile, or con≈øtant, or firm over all, and is the Paradi≈øe in it ≈øelf. It is an Angelical Air, which doth not fetch breath there as the living Soul, for the Life of Nature is Eternal in regard of the end; but it liveth and moveth in the Virtue of Gods word Eternally, ≈øine respiratione, or without breathing.

Therefore death cannot Reign in the Angelical world over the Nature, and over the Tree of Life, but is rather overcome by it (how much more by God) for the Tree of Life ≈øtands unmoveable: Therefore by the breaking of the fruit of this Tree, at the glorious coming of Chri≈øt, all ≈øhall come from death to life, and ≈øhall be freed and redeemed from death, Devil and Cur≈øe. La≈øtly, in its Spirit al≈øo it is of an Angelical Spirit‚ñ™ by the power of the word and Te≈øtimony of God. Thus namely, that the Dragon hath no power over it, but is conquered by the Spirit of the ≈øame, is ca≈øt out, and quite extruded and ca≈øt away; How much more th ‚Ä¢ n by God. Therefore ≈øeeing the Nature in her Spirit is the wind of the Almighty, and a going forth of the Light in which God dwelleth, and cannot come to that evil one, or may not fall into an evil, neither may it be bla≈øted or poi≈øoned by the breath of the old Serpent.

The Divine world in its being is compared to the mo≈øt noble body of the water and earth, as it were to a Heavenly body which is and are an E≈ø≈øential Spiritual Salt, as the mo≈øt noble and pure Gems, precious
≈øtones, and gli≈øtering Gold. In its Life it is the breath of the Almighty, a Soul and Life proceeding out of the mouth of God in and to an Eternal Life; and in its Spirit, the Spirit of the Lord it ≈øelf, who is God prai≈øed for ever. God is the Spirit‚ñ™ the Nature is the Soul or the Life, and the Elements are the Body: But be it known, that each world hath its proper Nature and Element, and that the one world is never changed into the other, neither can it be altered, nor one Principle general into another. Now each Principle hath its proper Spirit, Life and Body.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the third general Principle, namely of the Element.
div.p: GOd him≈øelf is all in all, out of him are all things according to the Spirit, by him are all things according to the word, and to him are all things according to the Providence or Confidence. Rom. 11. 36. Wi≈ød. 1. 7. Chap. 12. 1. Gen. 1. John 1. P≈øal. 104. 27, 28. 136. 25. 145. 15, 16.

The nature is all, but not in all; becau≈øe ≈øhe is not in God, who hath his own Nature, and the Elements al≈øo are not all, but ≈øomething only; which is a Salt. This ≈øomething is from God after the Spirit, from Nature after the Life and Soul, and from
the Spiritual water after the body. And again, the water out of the Salt; each world is, and doth flow out of the other,
The Nature ≈øtands to the Angelical world, and is a flowing out of the divine world; and the Elementary world is an overflowing of the Nature and Angelical world.

div.head: CHAP XI. Of the Principle of the fire, and its My≈øtery.
div.p: THere is a threefold fire, namely, the fire of the contrary Element, the fire of the Angels, and the fire of the Devils.

The fire of the contrary element is threefold. Fir≈øt before the fall, a ≈øtill re≈øting and unmanife≈øted fire, without a burning flame. div.head: CHAP. XVIII. Of the Image of God, after which Man is Created‚ñ™
div.p:

Even as Man in his true Manhood, after which he is di≈øtingui≈øhed from all other living Souls, a Spirit or Spiritual in and on his Spiritual Soul, and Mans Spirit cannot be ≈øeen, felt or known, otherwi≈øe then in his body, in which he dwelleth with all his fulne≈øs. The Image of God is threefold; Namely 1. the Image of the E≈ø≈øence e≈ø≈øentially, after man is, his own Image in his own proper E≈ø≈øence and Body: So Chri≈øt al≈øo is the e≈ø≈øential and bodily Image in God, even as Mans body in Man, and ≈øo is God in Chri≈øt, as Man is in his body, his own e≈ø≈øential ≈øelf-≈øub≈øi≈øting bodily, and per≈øonal Image. 2. The Image of that form, on the outward appearance of that form, Face and Members, 3. The Image of the living properties, Power, or what name ≈øoever it may be called. Here is manife≈øt the My≈øtery of the Image of God, and that God in Chri≈øt, and Chri≈øt in God was much ≈øooner a Man then we; for we are in all things fa≈øhioned after him, and ≈øo his counterfeit.

Chri≈øt the Image of God, and Man who is out of Gods Image and honour are thus di≈øtingui≈øhed; Namely, 1. As the Image and E≈ø≈øence. 2. As E≈ø≈øence and E≈ø≈øence. 3. As Spiritual, Heavenly and Divine, and as Souli≈øh, Terre≈øtrial and from beneath, that is as Adam and Adam, Man and Man, and as above and beneath. Now as E≈ø≈øence and E≈ø≈øence are one di≈øtinct from another; ≈øo is frame and frame. 1, The inward form of God, is the mo≈øt holy Godhead, which with all fulne≈øs dwelleth bodily in Chri≈øt. Of this form man hath received the Breath of the Almighty in a Heavenly Soul to his inward e≈ø≈øential form and true Manhood. 2. The bodily vi≈øible, palpabl and per≈øonal form of God, e≈ø≈øentially in which God per≈øonally appeared, and per≈øonally was made manife≈øt, is the fle≈øh of the word the body of Chri≈øt After this man hath a body of fle≈øh, bloud and bones, but not Divine, Spiritual and Heavenly, but Souli≈øh, Terre≈øtrial, and from beneath. 3. The manife≈øt face. „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and looks, and pre≈øence on the head, body and all Members, and their Powers and ≈øtrength. After this al≈øo is Man framed, and thus to be looked on; in which con≈øideration many My≈øteries may be ob≈øerved, although the ≈øpirit of Errour ≈øaith, as if God had no Head, Eyes, Ears, Face, No≈øe, Mouth, no Hands nor Feet, becau≈øe he is a Spirit‚ñ™ which rather befalls tho≈øe Spirits of Errour, he hath Eyes and ≈øeeth not, neither acknowledgeth the Image of God in Chri≈øt and in Man, hath Ears and heareth not, and a Heart, and under≈øtandeth nothing,

Further Man is made after Gods ≈øimilitude, and is like unto God; Namely 1. on the Heavenly Soul, Eternal and Immortal‚ñ™ and thence he is of God. 2. Like in Power, that he can do much, namely after his part, mea≈øure and weight. 3. Like in Glory, as a God, over all other Creatures a Lord and Ruler,

Good Reader here you mu≈øt know and ob≈øerve, that this great My≈øtery doth manife≈øt here, and Bringeth along the right Jehior let it be light, the day of the Revelation of the Son of Man, of which Chri≈øt ≈øaith‚ñ™ expre≈øly, Luke 17. 22. &c. On which the the Son of man is revealed, and that this is the Revelation and appearance
of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, of whom the Holy Apo≈øtles have prophe≈øied. 1 Pet. 1. 7. & 5. 1 Tim. 6. 14. 16. ‚Ä¢
Joh. 2. 28. Tit. 2. 13. 2 Tim 4. 8. & 2 The≈ø. 2. 8. Thus The Revelation or appearance of the coming is clearly di≈øtingui≈øhed. Mal. 3. Mat. 24. 30. And chiefly Rev. 12. He that hath Eyes let him ≈øee, and he that hath Ears let him hear, and an under≈øtanding Heart hearken unto it.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Of the My≈øtical Image, that is of the My≈øtery of God.
div.p:
THis is the My≈øtery of God, as was ≈øaid already, which is clear and manife≈øt on the Souli≈øh Adam and Terre≈øtrial Man from beneath, that namely above is the true Adam and Man, but beneath is only his Image. Concerning the My≈øtery of God in the Creation of Man, it is thus that God hath Created Man, a Man and Woman. Gen. 1. 27. And took the Woman out of the Man, Chap. 2. 21, 22. To ≈øhew the great My≈øtery of Chri≈øt, and of his Church, which is his Wife and ≈øpou≈øe, out of his fle≈øh and bones. Ephe≈ø. 5. 30, 31, 32. But the Divine, Spiritual and Heavenly Eve is threefold. 1. The mo≈øt holy Godhead it ≈øelf. 2. The Church of Chri≈øt. 3 The Heavenly Soul in Man. The Divine Eve as the mo≈øt Holy Godhead is the Mother of us all, and the right Jeru≈øalem which is from above. The Spiritual Eve as the Church of Chri≈øt is the Mother, the Spou≈øe of the Lamb. Now if we ask after the My≈øtery of God, how that may be made known, an≈øwer is, on man it may be known: There is but one man in one Per≈øon, but in it three witne≈ø≈øes of his ≈øub≈øtance, as Body, Soul and Spirit, and in ≈øeven Powers: The Spirit is always in ≈øtead of the Father, and is the Father him≈øelf al≈øo, and begetteth by the Soul, as by the true Mother, to him≈øelf a body, which is the Child and the Son, in which dwelleth all fulne≈øs. 3 La≈øtly God begets al≈øo a Son, and is a father after the Te≈øtimony, and that to all Creatures, and what ever

div.head: CHAP. XX. Of the Truth and Spirit, by which all Wi≈ødom is ju≈øtified.
div.p:
WHen we intend to ≈øpeak of the Wi≈ødom, it mu≈øt be done in the Spirit and Truth. Now nothing is Truth but only the Spirit, and the ≈øame can lead us into all Truth, can teach us all, and can tell us of things to come; for all Spirits are in ≈øubjection to him, he penetrates through them all, even as fire doth to Gold and Silver ≈øeven times, and the good that remaineth in it, it doth not undoe, but rather thinks that there is a ble≈ø≈øing in it, and bloweth into the ≈ømoking ‚Ä¢ lax, a fire of Life, Light and Fire, and in ‚Ä¢ u≈øeth it
≈øelf into the ≈øame, that it may be fitted for a new Creation, for a multiplication into many thou≈øands.

But nothing may attain unto Wi≈ødom, unle≈øs it be fir≈øt gone to the fire for a Tryal, even as the Gold cannot come to its glory, unle≈øs it be gone in the Cru≈øible through the con≈øuming fire ≈øeven times, that afterward it may be Baptized with Water and Spirit to a new birth, and become a new Gold, and become out of the ≈øame Spirit and Water increa≈øed into many thou≈øands, and as a Heavenly Gold, Spirit and Metal, whereby other inferiour metals may be turned into the ≈øub≈øtance of the be≈øt Gold. So it fareth with man that ≈øhall get Wi≈ødom, fir≈øt he mu≈øt be baptized with Fire, then with Water, and then with the Spirit, and all this is done in the Cru≈øible of the Terre≈øtrial man.

But all wi≈ødom is ≈øufficient through the Spirit, and in Truth, through Principia ≈øubordinata, & Concordantia, which do concenter afterward in a Harmony. The Principia contain the true beginning of every thing from whence it came, thither it doth return al≈øo, and from thence it is pre≈øerv'd al≈øo. The Subordinata contain the Order, ≈øtraitne≈øs and perfection of every thing, as they do hang one in another, ≈øtand and ≈øub≈øi≈øt one by another, even as a Ladder or Stairs, there mu≈øt not be one ≈øtep ami≈øs or wanting, el≈øe the ≈øubordinata are not true. La≈øtly this is a Concordance, that all things may agree one with another, and a Contrariety be no where found, ≈øeen or heard. in Ternarius and ∆≤nity, where one floweth out of another till to the number of ≈øeven of the Subordinata, which reach after the greater number till to Twelve.

At la≈øt the Harmony concentreth, and enclo≈øeth all, which taketh altogether in One, Three and Seven, and pre≈øents one as the other, namely the upper as the lower, and the lower as the upper; ≈øo that none be again≈øt the other, although they be ≈øo far di≈øtinct as God and Creature, Spirit and Soul, Heaven and Earth, yet one is in the other, the one is known by the other, and the one is ju≈øtified by the other, and that in Spirit and Truth. Search now and ≈øee, try and learn, hear, ob≈øerve, and judge what Wi≈ødom this is, and what Truth and Spirit is pre≈øented in this Book. The fool knoweth nothing of the Wi≈ødom, and doth not under≈øtand her way. Now all Spirit, Truth and Wi≈ødom reveal them≈øelve; in the≈øe three, and are thereby known and ju≈øtified, namely in a Divine Light, in a Divine Life, and in a Divine Love, where the≈øe three are in, on, and about man, there is really Spirit, Truth and Wi≈ødom. out, Rev. 16, 12. 4. E≈ød. 13. 4. I≈øa. 11. 11. Chap. 27. 13. Jer. 31. 8. Deut. 30. 4. Mica. 4. 6. 7. Rom. 11. 25. Yea whole I≈ørael and whole Juda will come again into their Countrey, and will turn to the Lord their God. Ho≈ø. 3,

La≈øtly, The la≈øt ≈øign of the coming of the Lord is when the Bea≈øt, and all Kings of the Earth, together with Gog and Magog, by the ≈øeduction of the three unclean Spirits into the Land of I≈ørael, and to the Valley of Jeho≈øaphat, and upon the Hill of I≈ørael come together to a Battel, &c. and are de≈øtroyed with fire from Heaven. Rev. 19, 19, 20, 21. Ezek. 3. 8. Joel 3. I≈øa. 24. 21, 22.
This is the end, then beginneth the Kingdom and Prie≈øthood of Melchi≈øedech, Halelujah,

body.trailer: Come Lord Je≈øus, and deliver us from the Evil One. Amen.

div.head: Conclu≈øion.
div.p: COurteous Reader, we conclude this our Jehior or Morning Light, and ≈øalute you in the Lord, from the Lord in the Spirit of Grace and Supplication, which the Lord will pour out over us all, through the Power from above, that we might find Grace before him at his coming, and may not be put to ≈øhame when he judgeth.

Reader, if you are a wellwi≈øher to Wi≈ødom, then take of us the Crumbs which we have gathered from the Lords Table, and accept of them till Melchi≈øedech cometh, and di≈øtributeth the Holy Shew-bread, and to drink of the New Wine of his distributing at the great Supper of the Nuptials of the Lamb in Paradi≈øe, the fruits whereof him≈øelf will
≈øet up. You are to give thanks with us to him, from whom all good gifts come from above the Father of Lights, praying‚ñ™ that he would inlighten us all, turn us to him, and make us happy for ever. This is according to the love of God, who≈øe dede≈øire is, that all men may be ≈øaved, and that all may come to the knowledge of the Truth: Therefore let us be merciful, loving and perfect, Even as our Heavenly Father is merciful, loving and perfect, that it may be known and revealed, that we are his Children.

But Curteous Reader, if you affect folly, and art a de≈øpi≈øer of Wi≈ødom, go to, and de≈øpi≈øe, but be ≈øure that you do not de≈øpi≈øe men herein, but God him≈øelf, who hath given us his Spirit, and from whom all Wi≈ødom cometh, and think that the Spirit of judgment will require an account of you in that day.

But Reader, if you are a Phari≈øee and Hypocrite, and ≈øeeke≈øt rather Honour from Men, then from God; We'll con≈øider
then, what the Lord ≈øaith, 1 Sam. 2. 30. He that honoureth me, him I will honour al≈øo, and he that de≈øpi≈øeth me, ≈øhall be de≈øpi≈øed again. And Chri≈øt ≈øaith, Mat. 10. 3 ‚Ä¢ . He that confe≈ø≈øeth me before men, him will I al≈øo confe≈øs before my Heavenly Father that is in Heaven. He that denieth me before men, him will I al≈øo deny before my Heavenly father.

But Reader, if you are a ≈øimple Heart, and art not fit for Wi≈ødom, then abide on, in, and by the fear of the Lord, in a Godly life; which fear is not only the beginning of Wi≈ødom, but al≈øo the end of Wi≈ødom, and it is no help to man, though he be able to ≈øpeak with an Angelical Tongue, and had all knowledge, and under≈øtood all My≈øteries, and had ≈øuch a faith, whereby he could remove Mountains, and withall had not the Love of God, which endured everlastingly, all will profit you nothing. Therefore ble≈ø≈øed are the Babes and ≈øucklings which know not the≈øe outward
things, for theirs is the Kingdom of God, becau≈øe the Spirit of God is declared in them. Therefore let no man be puffed up with Knowledge: And for our part we are not extol'd therewith, for Satan al≈øo doth buffet us with fists, and doth upbraid us with our ≈øhame. Therefore we humble our ≈øelves that the Lord may accept of us in mercy, Who giveth Grace to the humble, and beholdeth low things, and him that is of a contrite heart, and trembleth at his Word.

Lastly, This is the Conclu≈øion, that every one examine him≈øelf, and that according to the Spirit, Truth and Wi≈ødom, and no otherwi≈øe, whether God, Christ, and the Holy Gho≈øt be in him, which every one may know by his thoughts, Words and Works, in his affection, will, and plea≈øure, and in his Knowledge and Con≈øcience. Every good thing is from God, and of God, and not of Men. All Sin is from the Devil, who ≈øeduceth man, and leadeth him to perdition and destruction. Well be to him,
who ≈øeparates bad from good, rejects bad things, and maketh choice of good, and beareth fruit thereby.
The Lord Zeboah will at last take away the evil Eternally, and re≈øtore the good again, and return bad things to that evil one, and recompence it upon his head, Amen.
The Lord our God be gracious unto us, and help forward the works of his hands, yea, the works of his hands he will help forward, Amen.
Prai≈øed be the Lord that cometh, and ble≈ø≈øed be his glorious name. All the world be full of his Honour,

div.p: BE plea≈øed to under≈øtand, that ≈øome (≈ømall Number) of the≈øe Books in this Catalogue cannot ab≈øolutely be called Chymical, but have a very near affinity thereunto, the knowledge of natural Philo≈øophy being an Introduction to ≈øupernatural things; nor do I pretend to publi≈øh this as an ab≈øolute Collection of Engli≈øh Chymical Authors; (di≈øtru≈øting I may have forgotten ≈øome of common note) but rather as an E≈ø≈øay to provoke others (better able) to perfect it. Several of the≈øe Books I have drawn out of the Catalogues of And: Maun≈øel, William London, and the Mercurius Librarius; others I have more largely tran≈øcribed from the Books them≈øelves, with the Date when Printed, and in what Volume, as near as the ≈øhortne≈øs of my time would permit, having but a few days to Collect it; and therefore I crave excu≈øe for my mi≈øtakes, and leave the perfecting thereof to time, and other mens ingenuity, who ≈øhall plea≈øe to take the pains to add what ≈øhall come within the verge of their Knowledge, or be pre≈øented to their view.
